So the uh seven figures  give a thumbnail sketch. Father Antonio I- Isoleri was an Italian immigrant who became pastor of the first Italian parish in the United States. Saint Mar- Mary Magdalene dePazzi. His service as a spiritual and secular leader from eighteen seventy to nineteen twenty six was instrumental in shaping the future of South Philadelphia's Italian-American community. The church remains a worship site while maintaining its Italian identity to this day. Its former rectory serves as the Mario Lanza Institute and Museum, honoring the tenor who used to sing the Ave Maria in his old church. Dorothy Allen is the daughter of West Indian African American parents and was born and raised in South Philadelphia. She is the founder of the Barrett Educational Center in Point Breeze and worked to provide food, social services,  job training, and a safe haven for children and teens in the neighborhood. African Americans have formed part of the South Philadelphia community since the area's earliest days. By eighteen twenty the area around South Street contained nearly three quarters of Philadelphia's African American population. Many newcomers settled west of Broad Street in Point Breeze during the Great Migration of the twentieth century. Bill McIntyre was a longshoreman and a master welder for the Independent Pier Company. He marched as a comic in the Mummers Parade for many years before founding the Shooting Stars Fancy Brigade. The parade's first Fancy Brigade. He paraded with his neighbors on New Year's Day for seventy three years. The parade traces back to mid-seventeenth century roots. The New Year's traditions of South Philadelphia's first settlers, the Swedes, blended with the traditional Mummers play of the British Isles. After more than a century of informal merrymaking, the first official parade was in nineteen oh one. ((Fabula Conto)) works as an accountant for Marriott Hotels. She helps organize Philadelphia's version of Guadalupe celebration. She was also an active participant in negotiations to increase communication between the Philadelphia police and South Philadelphia's Mexican community. This community established around the Italian Market and is mainly from the state of Puebla. The Mexican population in South Philly has grown exponentially since two thousand and one. This is due in part to migration from New York City in the wake of the September eleventh attacks. Frank ((Snock)) was the son of Polish immigrants. In the early+ twentieth century he boxed under the name Johnny ((Coffey.)) The young fighter made enough money to open Snockey's Oyster House, A neighborhood landmark that has thrived over a hundred years and counting. During the greatest influx of European immigration into Philadelphia, the Washington Avenue wharves were owned by the Pennsylvania Railroad. {lipsmack} They served as a docking point for ships to unload food, finished goods, workers, and future Americans that would travel by train through the city and around the country. ((Ba Win)) is a Vietnamese refugee and a respected elder in South Philadelphia's Southeast Asian community. Active member as a volunteer, she teaches traditional Vietnamese cooking classes to young people and promotes health screenings for aging immigrants. South Philadelphia's been one of the chief destinations for the Vietnamese immigration in the ~USA since nineteen seventy five. Philadelphia has a higher percentage and numerical population of Vietnamese than New York City. Joe Tayoun's Lebanese immigrant grandparents established the family's roots in South Philly where they opened the legendary Middle East restaurant. An accomplished percussionist who learned his musical craft while working in his family business, Joe has performed across the United States, Europe, and North Africa. The Lebanese community in South Philadelphia dates back to the eighteen eighties.
